title: Elevated PD-1 and PD-L1 Levels: Investigating Positive Correlations in Immune Response Modulation
abstract: Programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) and its ligand PD-L1 are pivotal regulators in the immune checkpoint pathway, directly influencing the suppression of immune responses in various disease models, including cancer. This study systematically investigates the correlation between PD-1 and PD-L1 expression levels across different cell types and environmental conditions. Utilizing quantitative RT-PCR, flow cytometry, and immunohistochemical analysis, our results consistently demonstrate a positive correlation between the expression levels of PD-1 and PD-L1. This relationship suggests a potential feedback mechanism whereby increased PD-1 expression may upregulate PD-L1 levels, further contributing to the modulation of immune responses. Our findings underline the importance of co-targeting PD-1 and PD-Lifecycle to enhance therapeutic strategies in oncology and autoimmune diseases. Moreover, the data provide a foundational understanding that supports ongoing clinical trials exploring dual inhibitory strategies against both PD-1 and PD-L1 in the management of resistant neoplastic diseases.
